definitions: create false information or stories deliberately to deceive someone
make or build something by assembling parts or materials together
examples: The witness fabricated evidence to frame the innocent suspect
She fabricated an elaborate excuse for missing the important meeting
Workers fabricate steel beams in the factory for construction projects
The engineer fabricated a custom bracket to solve the design problem

definitions: temporarily lose consciousness and fall down due to lack of oxygen to the brain
become weak barely noticeable or difficult to perceive clearly
examples: She fainted from the heat during the outdoor ceremony
The patient might faint if they stand up too quickly
The pencil marks were so faint I could barely read them
We heard faint music coming from the neighbor's apartment

definitions: change information or documents dishonestly to make them incorrect or misleading
show that a theory or statement is incorrect through evidence or testing
examples: The accountant falsified records to hide the company's losses
Someone falsified my signature on these important legal documents
The new evidence falsified their original hypothesis about climate patterns
Scientists tried to falsify the theory through rigorous experimental testing

definitions: lose strength momentum or purpose and begin to fail or give way
speak or move in an unsteady way showing uncertainty or weakness
examples: The economy began to falter after years of steady growth
Her confidence faltered when she saw the large audience
He faltered over his words during the difficult conversation
The runner faltered in the final stretch of the marathon

definitions: make someone aware of or acquainted with something through study or experience
examples: Please familiarize yourself with the emergency procedures before starting work
The teacher familiarized students with the new software during training

definitions: perform progress or succeed in a particular way or to a particular degree
examples: How did you fare in your job interview yesterday afternoon
The team fared poorly in the tournament without their star player

definitions: release gas from the intestines through the anus making a sound or smell
examples: The baby farted loudly during the quiet church service
My dog always farts after eating beans or dairy products

definitions: attach or join one thing to another firmly using a device or method
examples: Please fasten your seatbelt before the plane takes off
She fastened the necklace clasp around her neck carefully

definitions: understand something complicated or mysterious after much thought
measure the depth of water using a special line or device
examples: I cannot fathom why she made such a risky decision
It's hard to fathom the complexity of the human brain
Sailors used to fathom the ocean depth before modern technology
The captain ordered the crew to fathom the harbor entrance

definitions: cause someone to become very tired from physical or mental effort
examples: The long hike fatigued everyone in our camping group
Constant stress will fatigue your mind and affect your health

definitions: show preference for or give support to one person or thing over another
do something helpful or kind for someone as an act of kindness
examples: The judge seemed to favour the prosecution throughout the trial
Most voters favour candidates who promise lower taxes
Could you favour me with your assistance on this project
She favoured her friends by sharing her secret family recipe

definitions: mark or save something as preferred or liked especially in digital interfaces
examples: I always favourite recipes that turn out perfectly
Don't forget to favourite this website for easy access later

definitions: show excessive affection or admiration in a way that seems insincere to gain favor
examples: The employees fawned over the CEO during her office visit
Critics accused him of fawning over celebrities at the gala

definitions: send documents electronically through telephone lines using a fax machine to create copies
examples: Please fax the signed contract to our office by noon
Can you fax me the invoice for our records today

definitions: disturb upset or disconcert someone causing them to lose composure or confidence
examples: The hostile crowd didn't faze the experienced public speaker
Nothing seems to faze her even in stressful emergency situations

definitions: eat and drink abundantly especially at a special meal or celebration
examples: The family will feast on turkey and stuffing this Thanksgiving
We feasted at the wedding reception until late at night

definitions: cover or decorate something with feathers or feather-like materials
turn an oar or propeller blade to reduce resistance when moving
examples: Native Americans would feather arrows for better flight accuracy
The costume designer feathered the dress with ostrich plumes
The rower must feather the oar between each powerful stroke
Pilots feather propellers to reduce drag during engine failure

definitions: pretend to be affected by a feeling state or injury that is not genuine
examples: She feigned illness to avoid the boring company meeting
The soccer player feigned injury to waste time

definitions: make a deceptive movement especially in sports or combat to mislead an opponent
examples: The boxer feinted left before throwing a powerful right hook
The quarterback feinted a pass then ran with the ball

definitions: cut down trees for timber or to clear land for other uses
knock down or cause to fall with force especially a person or animal
examples: Loggers felled dozens of pine trees in the forest yesterday
The storm felled power lines throughout the entire neighborhood
The boxer felled his opponent with one powerful uppercut punch
The hunter felled the deer with a single well-aimed shot

definitions: make or convert fibers into felt by matting pressing and condensing them together
examples: The artist felted wool fibers to create colorful wall hangings
She learned to felt old sweaters into useful household items

definitions: defend oneself or protect from harm difficulty or unwanted things
examples: The mother bird will fend off predators from her nest
He had to fend for himself after moving out

definitions: undergo or cause to undergo fermentation where sugars convert to acids gases or alcohol
incite or stir up disorder unrest or trouble in a group or society
examples: The grapes ferment in barrels to produce wine
Yeast helps the bread dough ferment and rise properly
Radical ideas began to ferment revolution among the oppressed citizens
Social media can ferment discord in divided communities

definitions: search for something persistently and thoroughly often for hidden information
examples: Journalists ferret out corruption in government offices
The detective ferreted through old files for overlooked clues

definitions: transport people or vehicles across water regularly on a boat or ship
examples: The boat ferries passengers across the river every hour
We need to ferry supplies to the island before winter

definitions: add substances to soil to make it more productive for growing plants
join male and female reproductive cells to begin development of new life
examples: Farmers fertilize their fields every spring before planting crops
You should fertilize your lawn twice yearly for best results
The bee helps fertilize flowers as it collects nectar
Doctors can fertilize eggs outside the body for some couples

definitions: become infected and filled with pus typically referring to wounds or sores
become worse or more intense especially bad feelings or situations over time
examples: The untreated cut began to fester and required medical attention
Without proper cleaning wounds can fester and cause serious problems
Resentment festered between the neighbors for years after the dispute
Don't let anger fester inside you talk about your feelings

definitions: go to a place to get something or someone and bring them back
examples: Could you fetch my glasses from the bedroom please
The dog loves to fetch tennis balls at the park

definitions: honor or entertain someone lavishly typically with an elaborate party or celebration
examples: The town will fete the returning Olympic champion next week
They feted the retiring professor with a grand dinner party

definitions: restrain someone with chains or shackles or restrict freedom of action
examples: Guards used to fetter prisoners to prevent their escape
Bureaucratic rules fetter innovation in many large companies

definitions: have a prolonged and bitter quarrel or dispute with someone over time
examples: The two families have feuded over property boundaries for generations
The actors continued to feud publicly after the movie wrapped

definitions: tell a small or trivial lie especially to avoid minor trouble or embarrassment
examples: Children often fib about brushing their teeth before bed
He fibbed about his age on the dating app profile

definitions: play the violin especially in a casual or folk music style
tinker with something in an aimless way or make minor adjustments
examples: Grandpa loves to fiddle bluegrass tunes on his old violin
She learned to fiddle at summer music camp in Tennessee
Stop fiddling with your phone during our important conversation
He fiddled with the radio dial trying to find clear reception

definitions: delay or obstruct legislation by making long speeches in a parliamentary setting
examples: The senator threatened to filibuster the controversial bill all night
Opposition members often filibuster to prevent votes on unpopular measures

definitions: remove bones from meat or fish to prepare it for cooking or eating
examples: The chef will fillet the salmon for tonight's special dish
I need to fillet these fish before grilling them

definitions: complete the last details of a plan agreement or arrangement to make it ready
examples: We need to finalise the contract before the deadline tomorrow
The committee will finalise their recommendations at today's meeting

definitions: complete the last details of a plan agreement or arrangement to make it ready
examples: Let's finalize the wedding plans this weekend
The team will finalize the project proposal by Friday

definitions: take impressions of someone's fingerprints for identification or security purposes
examples: Police fingerprint all suspects during the booking process
The bank will fingerprint new employees for background checks

definitions: inform on someone to authorities betraying their trust or confidence
examples: He threatened to fink on his friends to avoid jail
Nobody likes people who fink to the boss

definitions: make something resistant to fire or flames through special treatment or materials
examples: Building codes require contractors to fireproof all public buildings
We need to fireproof these curtains for the theater

definitions: split or crack to form a long narrow opening especially in rock or earth
examples: The earthquake caused the ground to fissure dangerously
Extreme temperatures can fissure concrete over time

definitions: fight someone using only fists and hands without weapons in physical combat
examples: The two men began to fistfight outside the bar
Students who fistfight face immediate suspension from school

definitions: produce bubbles and make a hissing sound like carbonated drinks
examples: The soda began to fizz when I opened the bottle
Champagne should fizz gently when poured into glasses

definitions: wave or swing wildly and uncontrollably typically arms or objects
beat grain with a tool to separate seeds from stalks
examples: The drowning swimmer flailed desperately in the rough water
She flailed her arms to ward off the attacking bees
Farmers used to flail wheat by hand before modern machinery
Workers would flail grain on the threshing floor

definitions: come off in thin flat pieces or layers from a surface
fail to appear or follow through on a commitment informally
examples: Paint began to flake off the old wooden fence
My sunburned skin started to flake after a few days
Don't flake on me we have dinner reservations tonight
She always flakes when we make plans to study together

definitions: be positioned at the side of someone or something especially for protection
examples: Bodyguards flank the president whenever she appears in public
Tall trees flank both sides of the historic driveway

definitions: move up and down or back and forth with quick motions like wings
examples: Birds flap their wings rapidly during takeoff
The flag will flap loudly in the strong wind

definitions: burn with sudden bright flame or blaze up with intense light briefly
gradually spread outward becoming wider at one end
examples: The match flared brightly in the dark cave
Tempers flared during the heated political debate
Her dress flares beautifully from the waist down
The trumpet flares at the end for better sound

definitions: make something flat or flatter by pressing crushing or smoothing it down
examples: Use a rolling pin to flatten the cookie dough
The bulldozer will flatten this area for new construction

definitions: give excessive or insincere praise to someone often for personal gain
examples: He tried to flatter his boss before asking for promotion
Don't flatter me I know the presentation needs work
